content:  survival socks pattern by elin stoodley/panda go urgh you will need 3 mm crochet hook or any size hook to obtain gauge 2 balls of drops fabel 4ply colour 674 - bourgogne print a pair of scissors darning needle 1 stitch marker or a safety pin ruler/measuring tape  named survival socks after i made my first pair of socks and felt that having this skill increased my chances of surviving the forthcoming zombie apocalypse don t ask me exactly how they will improve your chances of living but i m pretty confident that being able to fashion your own footwear in a crisis is a pretty good thing page 1 notes the pattern describes how to make a sock that will fit uk adult shoe sizes 3-8 the pattern is written using uk crochet terms gauge/gauge to make these socks you will need to know how to do chains double_crochet increase and decrease slip it can be a good idea to check your gauge so that stitch and work in back loops you are sure the sock will fit especially if you are using a different yarn the sock is worked from the toe up some sewing is required to finish the sock the gauge should be roughly the toe foot and leg are worked in a continuous 23dc in 26 row to make a square 10x10 cm round the row are not joined together with a slip make a swatch of 23 double_crochet and 26 row if the square is stitch they simply continue on top of each other too large try a smaller hook if it s too small try a mark the start of the round with a stitch bigger hook marker/safety pin or a piece of yarn in a contrasting colour and move the marker as you start a new after you have finished the toe check if the sock fits round around your foot the width will stay the same for all of the foot you can adapt the length of the foot to fit the heel and cuff are worked back and forth in row exactly to your size and you need to turn you work after each row key chain s chain s st s stitch es slip_stitch slip_stitch double_crochet double_crochet decrease double_crochet 2 stitches together decreasing stitch xx total stitch count in round/row back loop working in the back loop of a sts creates the ribbed effect of the cuff instead of going through both loops of the sts only work through the back loop and leave the front loop exposed to create a ridge picture 1 picture 1 page 2 toe foundation chain chain 13 picture 2 row 1 double_crochet in the second chain from hook double_crochet in the next 10 chain 3 double_crochet in the next chain continue working back along the foundation chain but do not turn your work double_crochet in the next 10 chain 2 double_crochet in the next chain that already has your first double_crochet
